--- title: Shoulder Region subtitle: Musculoskeletal overview --- ![Thorax and Shoulder girdle (posterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image204 gray1918 Posterior view of the thorax and shoulder girdle.gif){#fig-gray1918-image20} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - General - Ch16 Shoulder @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 - Sport therapy for the shoulder: evaluation, rehabilitation, and return to sport @ellenbeckerSportTherapyShoulder2017 - Examination - Ch19 Screening the Shoulder and Upper Extremity @heickGoodmanSnyderDifferential2023 - Manual Tx - Ch22 Orthopaedic Manual Physical Therapy of the Shoulder Joint Complex @wiseOrthopaedicManualPhysical2015 - Surgery - Synopsis of Shoulder @srikumaranSynopsisShoulderSurgery2021. ::: There are 3 major axes of the shoulder: 1. Transverse Axis: Allows movements of flexion and extension in the *sagittal plane* @jonesProjectFoundations2025 1. Antero-posterior axis: Allows movements in the *frontal plane* @jonesProjectFoundations2025 1. Vertical axis: runs through the intersection of the sagittal and frontal planes and controls the movements of flexion and extension @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Bones The Shoulder complex is made up of 3 bones: 1. [Humerus](#humerus) 1. [Clavicle](#clavicle) 1. [Scapula](#scapula) ## Humerus {#humerus} [Read more about the humerus here]({{< var ref-humerus-bone.path >}}) ## Clavicle {#clavicle} ![Left Clavicle (superior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image200 gray1918 Left clavicle. Superior surface.gif){#fig-gray1918-image200} ![Left clavicle (inferior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image201 gray1918 Left clavicle. Inferior surface.gif){#fig-gray1918-image201} [Read more about the clavicle here]({{< var ref-clavicle-bone.path >}}) ## Scapula {#scapula} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ![Left Scapula (Anterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image202 gray1918 Left scapula. Costal surface.gif){#fig-gray19180image202} ::: ::: {.column} ![Left scapula (Posterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image203 gray1918 Left scapula. Dorsal surface.gif){#fig-gray1918-image203} ::: ::: ![Left Scapula (Lateral view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image205 gray1918 Left scapula. Lateral view.gif){#fig-gray1918-image205} [Read more about the scapula here]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.path >}}) # Joints The Shoulder complex is made up of 3 joints and 1 pseudo joint: 1. [SCJ]({{< var ref-sternoclavicular-joint.path >}}) provides *gross* movement of the clavicle @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. 1. The [ACJ]({{< var ref-acromioclavicular-joint.path >}}) provides fine motor control of the clavicle @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. 1. The [glenohumeral joint](#glenohumeral-joint) 1. The [scapulothoracic (pseudo) joint](#scapulothoraic-joint) ![Left Acromioclavicular and Glenohumeral joints (anterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Syndesmology/image326 gray1918 The left shoulder and acromioclavicular joints, and the proper ligaments of the scapula.gif){#fig-gray1918-image326} ![Right Glenohumeral joint capsule (Anterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Syndesmology/image327 gray1918 Capsule of shoulder-joint (distended). Anterior aspect.gif){#fig-gray1918-image327} ## Sternoclavicular Joint {#sternoclavicular-joint} [Read more about the Sternoclavicular (SCJ) here]({{< var ref-sternoclavicular-joint.path >}}) ## Acromioclavicular joint {#acromioclavicular-joint} The acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) is an articulation The ACJ has poor stability since the joint surfaces do not interlock making it prone to dislocations @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The acromion aspect of the joint is slightly convex and faces supero-antero-medially @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The clavicular aspect is flat or slightly convex and faces infero-postero-laterally Since these two facets can be flat or even both convex, they have poor joint congruity and in 30% of cases, an intra-articular fibrocartilage meniscus is present to improve congruency @jonesProjectFoundations2025. This joint's stability is augmented by 2 extra-articular ligaments for stability: [trapezoid lig.]({{< var ref-trapezoid-ligament.path >}}) and [conoid lig.]({{< var ref-conoid-ligament.path >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. [Read more about the Acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) here]({{< var ref-acromioclavicular-joint.path >}}) ## Glenohumeral joint {#glenohumeral-joint} [Read more about Glenohumeral Joint (GHJ)]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.path >}}) ## Scapulothoraic Joint {#scapulothoracic-joint} The Scapulothoracic Joint is considered a "pseudo joint" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 [Read more about the Scapulothoracic joint (STJ) here]({{< var ref-scapulothoracic-joint.path >}}) # Physiologic Area - Suprahumeral/Subacromial space # Ligaments "(GH Ligs) Together with the coracohumeral ligament, these ligaments form a Z-pattern on the anterior aspect of the shoulder (Fig. 16-6).3 In the midrange of rotation, the G-H ligaments are relatively lax" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Flexion & Extension Flexion and extension are movements of the shoulder that occur in the *sagittal plane* about a *transverse axis* @jonesProjectFoundations2025. | Movement | GHJ | Scapulohumeral | Total | |-|-|-|-| | Extension | | | 45-50° | | Flexion | 120° | 60° | 180° | : Normal ROM for shoulder flexion and extension @jonesProjectFoundations2025 {.striped} # Abduction & Adduction {#abduction-adduction} Abduction and adduction of the shoulder refers to frontal/coronal plane movement occurring about an antero-posterior axis. Normal abduction is 180° @jonesProjectFoundations2025. During abduction, the should complex made up of the [GHJ](#glenohumeral-joint), [ACJ](#acromioclavicular-joint) and [STJ](#scapulothoraic-joint) work together in 3 distinct phases to complete the whole range of motion. 1. 0-60° abduction takes place *only* at the glenohumeral joint @jonesProjectFoundations2025. 1. 60-180° is a combination of glenohumeral joint *and* the scapulothoracic joint @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ## Abduction There are 4 abductor muscles that form a force coupling of shoulder abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - Glenohumeral - deltoid - Supraspinatus - Scapulothoracic joint (upward rotation) - Serratus anterior - Upper trapezius During abduction, the [subscapularis]({{< var ref-subscapularis.action >}}), [infraspinatus]({{< var ref-infraspinatus.action >}}), and [teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.action >}}) draw the humeral the infero-medially during abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {.callout-note} The [biceps brachii long head]({{< var ref-biceps-brachii-long-head.action >}}) is also involved in abduction and a rupture will result in ~20% decrease in abduction *strength* @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: ### Pure abduction Pure abduction occurs in the frontal plane. - Component III of lateral deltoid recruits first - IV and V of posterior deltoid recruit immediately after @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - Component II (anterior delt) recruits after the first 20-30° @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ### Scapular plane abduction Scapular plane exists between the sagittal and frontal planes. 30° from the frontal plane @jonesProjectFoundations2025. 1. II (anterior deltoid) and III (lateral deltoid) are recruited first @jonesProjectFoundations2025. 1. IV and V (posterior deltoid) and I (Anterior deltoid) are recruited progressively later @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ### External rotation into abduction 1. II (anterior deltoid) contracts at the start ::: {.callout-note} IV and V (Posterior deltoid) do not contract at all during this movement @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: ### IR to abduction "recruitment order reverses" @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Axial Rotation The "neutral" position in axial rotation is where the elbow is flexed to 90° and the forearm is in the sagittal plane. ::: {.callout-note} Another "neutral" position is at 30° of internal rotation where the rotator muscles are at equilibrium @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: External rotation # Horizontal abduction & adduction # Stabilization ## Passive The shoulder maintains its passive stability by using multiple structures arranged reciprocally so when one structure is lax, the other is tightened @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. This allows the shoulder to have large degrees of freedom and ROM while limiting translation and rotation of the GHJ surfaces @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. - GH ligaments - Capsule - Posterior capsule - Glenoid labrum ## Active - GHJ - RTC - Shoulder elevation - Rhomboids - SA # Bursae According to Dutton @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020, the *synovium* of the *GH Joint Capsule* forms multiple bursae in shoulder complex @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. - Subacromial bursae (Subdeltoid Bursae) @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 - Lies on the superior aspect of the joint @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 - Largest bursae of the shoulder complex @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 "It also forms variously sized bursae, the largest of which, the subacromial or subdeltoid bursa, lies on the superior aspect of the joint (see later)." @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Muscles **Transverse muscles** (@tbl-shoulder-transverse-muscle-group-oian )press the humeral head against the glenoid cavity @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The **longitudinal muscles** (@tbl-shoulder-longitudinal-muscle-group-oian) support the upper limb and prevent inferior disarticulation when carrying heavy objects @jonesProjectFoundations2025. These muscles act to maintain or return the humeral head to the glenoid @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {#tbl-shoulder-transverse-muscle-group-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Transverse Shoulder muscles' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Infraspinatus Infraspinous Fossa of Scapula Greater tubercle of Humerus Suprascapular n.
C4 - C6		 GHJ: ER, Stabilization
Subscapularis Subscapular fossa Lesser tubercle of Humerus Upper Subscapular n.
Lower Subscapular n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: IR, Stabilization
Supraspinatus Supraspinous Fossa of scapula Greater tubercle of Humerus Suprascapular n.
C4 - C6		 GHJ: Initiates abduction, Stabilization
Teres minor Greater tubercle of Humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: ER, Weak adduction
``` ::: ::: ::: {#tbl-shoulder-longitudinal-muscle-group-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Longitudinal Shoulder muscles' execution_count=2} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Anterior deltoid Lateral third of clavicle Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Flexion, IR, Adduction
Biceps brachii Long head Supraglenoid tubercle of scapula
Adjacent rim of Glenoid Labrum		 Radial tuberosity
Bicipital aponeurosis		 Musculocutaneous n.
C5 - C6		 Elbow: Flexion, Supination
GHJ: Flexion, Stabilization of humeral head during deltoid contraction, Abduction, IR
Biceps brachii Short head Coracoid process Radial tuberosity
Bicipital aponeurosis		 Musculocutaneous n.
C5 - C6		 Elbow: Flexion, Supination
GHJ: Flexion, Stabilization of humeral head during deltoid contraction, Abduction, IR
Lateral deltoid Acromion Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Abduction
Pectoralis major Clavicle (medial half)
Sternum
Costal cartilages 1-6
Rectus sheath (anterior layer)		 Humerus (crest of greater tubercle) Lateral pectoral n.
Medial pectoral n.
C5 - T1		 Entire muscle: Adduction, IR
Clavicular & Sternocostal parts: Flexion, Aids in respiration when shoulder is fixed
Posterior deltoid Scapular spine Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Extension, ER, Abduction
Triceps brachii lateral head Posterior humerus just *proximal* to radial groove
Lateral intermuscular septum		 Olecranon of Ulna Radial n.
C6 - C8		 Elbow: Extension
Triceps brachii Long head Infraglenoid tubercle of Scapula Olecranon of Ulna Radial n.
C6 - C8		 Elbow: Extension
GHJ: Extension, Adduction
Triceps brachii medial head Posterior humerus just distal to radial groove
Medial intermuscular septum		 Olecranon of Ulna Radial n.
C6 - C8		 Elbow: Extension
``` ::: ::: # Stabilization - Anterior shoulder - Coracobrachialis # Pain ::: {.callout} - Clinical Considerations of Upper Back Shoulder and Arm Pain @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 ::: # MMT ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Flexion MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 - ext MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 - Abduction MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 - Adduction MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 - Horizontal abd MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 - Hor adduction MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: # Biomechanics ## Arm Elevation - SCAP UR: end range: post tilt and ER - End position: inf angle at midaxillary line - GHJ: humeral elevation and lateral rotation, inf glide of humerus - SCJ: elevation and post rotation and retraction # Evaluation Inventory ## Prone - Start at the superior angle of the scapula - Palpate - [Upper trapezius]({{< var ref-upper-trapezius.path >}}) - [Levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.path >}}) - [Rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.path >}}) - [Rhomboid minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor >}}) - [Middle trapezius]({{< var ref-middle-trapezius.path >}}) - Overall rib mobility - Use medial/ulnar side of your carpals to depress and upwardly rotate the scapula to test scapulothoracic mobility - Work on the rhomboids but bringing the scapula up and driving your fingers underneath the scapula - Palpate - Supraspinatus (above spine of scap) - [Infraspinatus]({{< var ref-infraspinatus.palpation >}}) - [Teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.palpation >}}) - [Teres major]({{< var ref-teres-major.palpation >}}) - [Latissimus dorsi]({{< var ref-latissimus-dorsi.palpation >}}) ## Supine - [Anterior→Posterior GHJ glide to assess joint mobility, tendon gliding, and capsular mobility]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.a-p-glide >}}) - [Superior→inferior GHJ glide assessment]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.sup-inf-glide >}}) - [Subscapularis]({{< var ref-subscapularis.palpation >}}) # Treatment ## Prone - GHJ P→A glide - GHJ Sup→Inf Glide - Upper trapezius - [Levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.release >}}) - [Rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.release >}}) and [minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor.release >}}) - middle trapezius - Lower trapezius - [Latissimus Dorsi]({{< var ref-latissimus-dorsi.release >}}) - Press between the ribs when working through the muscles in the back - When working on [serratus anterior]({{< var ref-serratus-anterior.release >}}), apply your pressure *on* the ribs since the muscle belly attaches *on* the ribs @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - RTC - [Supraspinatus]({{< var ref-supraspinatus.palpation >}}) - [Infraspinatus]({{{< var ref-infraspinatus.palpation >}}}) - [Teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.palpation >}}) - [Teres major]({{< var ref-teres-major.release >}}) ## Supine - [Supraspinatus]({{< var ref-supraspinatus.release >}}) - [Upper trapezius]({{< var ref-upper-trapezius.release >}}) - Inferior clavicle - [Subclavius]({{< var ref-subclavius.release >}}) - [Pectoralis major clavicular insertion]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.release >}}) - Anterior GHJ - Tendon and capsule pin while posteriorly gliding the humeral head - Superior GHJ - Inferior glide humeral head while bringing the arm into abduction - [Subscapularis release]({{< var ref-subscapularis-release >}}) - [1st rib inferior mobilization with scalene release]({{< var ref-1st-rib-bone.release >}}) - [Scapula depression and superior glide with movement and Upper trapezius release]({{< var ref-scapulothoracic-joint.release >}}) - Median nerve tensioning - Radial nerve tensioning - Brachial plexus axillary release # Special tests ::: {.callout-important} Special tests are useful when attempting to diagnose the integrity of a certain structure, but should not distract you from taking an [inventory](#inventory) of all of the surrounding structures. ::: - RTC - Subscap: Bear hug, Liftoff test - Champagne test - Hornblower's test - Labral tear - Clunk test - SLAP Tear - Speed's test (and bicipital tendinitis) - O'brien's test - Anterior impingement - Hawkins-Kennedy test - Posterior impingement - Posterior internal impingement test - Posterior instability - Jerk test - Inferior instability - Sulcus sign - Anterior dislocation - Apprehension Test (Crank test) - Fulcrum test - Posterior dislocation # Diagnosis ## Considerations before using special tests: Special tests for the shoulder have multiple issues. :::{layout-ncol="3"} ### Poor Gold Standards - Poor convergent validity: Special tests for the shoulder are based on MRI and ultrasounds, which are poor gold standards @salamhItTimePut2020. ### Poor Tissue Isolation (Specificity) - In empty can for “ supra” 9 shoulder mm active, - During full can test 8 other mm were active ### Pain is unreliable - Hyperalgesia: Areas with increased inflammatory markers can cause unrelated areas to be sensitive to certain positions. For example the subacromial bursa has high concentrations of substance P and pro-inflammatory cytokines and is often aggravated by the Empty can test @salamhItTimePut2020. - Allodynia: Pain is not directly related to tissue damage @salamhItTimePut2020. ::: # ROM interventions | Exercise | Movement | Scapula | |-|-|-| | T | 30° above the transverse plane
scapular plane flexion | retraction | | Y | Scapular flexion | Retraction + upward rotation + posterior tilt | | I | Pure Flexion | Retraction + upward rotation + posterior tilt | - Shoulder Ws - Shoulder WERs {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6eG45K29L0 >}} {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VEx4y40rpM >}} {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-OwrGCw50fQ >}}
